content:

It seems to mostly crash when clicking on a link or button.

Please note that from the very beginning when I started using Firefox close to a year ago, I had a specific bug that has never been solved (but it never caused crashes in the past). What happens is any type of pop-up menu does not open properly and the pop-up itself "crashes" when you try and open it (e.g. auto fill pop up when you focus an input, context menu pop up, drop-down menu for various Firefox actions in the toolbar, etc.), but it does eventually open with several attempts. title: Confusing message appeared on address bar
content:
I'd been browsing the web for a while today when Firefox randomly showed a message by the address bar, saying:

"Start your search in the address bar to see suggestions from Google and your browsing history. Okay, Got It."

What is this message trying to say?

Is it to inform me that searches can now be performed in the address bar? That feature has been around for like 10 years!

Is it a plea for me to stop using the search bar?

Is it a tip for new users who don't know what the address bar can do? If so, why am I seeing it when I've been using Firefox nearly 20 years.

And what does the word "start" mean in this context? That's confusing.

And what does my browsing history have to do with performing a web search? Searching the web and searching history are two completely unrelated tasks with nothing in common other than the fact that the address bar provides access to both.

title: bloqueo por firefox de una pagina web
content:
firefox me bloquea el acceso a la veb loader to,me pone esto: No se ha conectado: Posible problema de seguridad

Firefox ha detectado una potencial amenaza de seguridad y no ha continuado a loader.to porque este sitio web requiere una conexión segura.

¿Qué puede hacer al respecto?

loader.to tiene una política de seguridad llamada HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS), que significa que Firefox solo puede conectarse a él de forma segura. No puede añadir una excepción para visitar este sitio.

El problema está probablemente en el sitio web, y no hay nada que pueda hacer para resolverlo.

Si está en una red corporativa o utilizando un antivirus, puede ponerse en contacto con el equipo de asistencia para obtener ayuda. También puede notificar el problema al administrador del sitio web.

esto lo hace en mi ordenador portatil,sin embargo en mi pc con el mismo firefox actualizados los dos puedo acceder a loader to sin problemas.Paso el antivirus virus total y me da todo verde.RARO,RARO...

title: An image on my website that displays using Firefox iOS, doesn't display on the desktop version of Firefox.
content:
Hi there,

I edit a Squarespace website https://weathertree.com.au/ via an up to date Firefox browser on a Mac mini desktop OS 11.5.2. An image of the tree poster in the product block (right side) on the homepage just doesn't display.

It used to display last time looked a few months ago. Now something has changed. I think it has to do with the desktop browser, but I don't know what setting to toggle.

Using Firefox with a private window, the image also doesn't display.

Using Chrome, the image displays.

Using Firefox on an iPhone 12 and on an iPad the image displays.

I have emptied the cache in Firefox on the desktop, quit and restarted. Also restarted my modem. Still the image doesn’t display. Squarespace support tell me the image displays for them, but it doesn't for me. What else can I do?

Thanks in advance

Phil

title: Maximized(not fullscreen) firefox top edge bleeding into another monitor above.
content:
I've completely identified the problem(maybe). But I don't think any community help can fix this. Probably needs mozilla's attention for this. I just don't know how to get that attention.

Windows 10. This happends when display is on a 'OverUnder' setup, making window maximized(not F11 fullscreen mode.) in bottom display introduces white(usually) stripe bleeding into top display.

Some properties of this bug.

  • Taskbar hides this stripe. So most bottom-taskbar people can't see this.
  • It sometimes grabs normal firefox titlebar so It's colored and sometimes you can see tabs.
  • Enabling windows default titlebar fixes this problem because (obviously)default windows behavior is not broken. But it's ugly&unnecessarily uses space.

This bug is combination of Windows 10 maximize animation and poor handing of that animation by firefox. When you grab any window and maximize it. You can see that window doesn't just instantly becomes maximized, rather they start from just little bit smaller than maximized. When Firefox is playing this animiation, for some reason, only top edge introduces white stripe; And that white stripe just moves over to other monitor. You should be able to see this animation even if you don't have second monitor. Have to be focused because it's fast.
